data.title: Commodities: OPEC+ Set For Another Supply Increase
data.description:
By Warren Patterson, Head of Commodities Strategy, and Ewa Manthey, Commodities Strategist

Energy - OPEC+ set to meet

The oil market is on track to settle lower this week as market participants digest the implications of US sanctions on Russian oil flows. Clearly, the price action suggests that the market is not convinced that we will lose a significant amount of Russian oil supply. Yesterday’s meeting between President Trump and President Xi only served to strengthen this conviction, with Russian oil flows to China apparently not part of broader talks between the two leaders. This is important for the market given that China imports around 2m b/d of Russian oil. It’s the only buyer that could meaningfully increase its purchases if India reduced its imports of Russian crude.

On Sunday, OPEC+ is set to meet. It appears likely that the group will agree to another 137k b/d supply increase for December. The uncertainty surrounding sanctions on Russia also supports this increase. However, the move will only reinforce the bearish outlook for the market, adding to the substantial surplus expected through 2026. Obviously, this is assuming no supply shocks from Russia.

Middle distillate cracks remain well-supported, with lingering uncertainty over the impact of sanctions on Russian diesel exports. The ICE gasoil crack is holding around $30/bbl, after a strong rally since mid-October. However, the latest data from Insights Global shows that gasoil inventories in the Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp (ARA) region increased by 109kt WoW to 2.27mt, which saw its gap to the 5-year average widen. In Singapore, meanwhile, after a significant increase in middle distillate stocks the previous week, stocks declined by 6.25m barrels over the last week.

US natural gas Dec’25 futures rallied 3.7% yesterday, and the strength has continued in early morning trading today. The move higher comes despite US natural gas inventories rising by 74 bcf over the last week, in line with expectations and above the 5-year average increase of 67 bcf. Instead, the market appears to be focused on forecasts for cooler weather, which should prove supportive of demand.

Agriculture - China to buy 25mt of US soybeans annually

CBOT soybean futures extended their upward rally, with prices surging more than 1.9% at one stage yesterday. This was after President Donald Trump announced that China would immediately purchase large volumes of US soybeans. Later, the US administration said that China agreed to buy 12mt of soybeans between now and January, with a further commitment to purchase at least 25mt annually over the next three years. The announced purchases are largely in line with China's imports of US soybeans prior to the trade war. For reference, China imported around 22mt of US soybeans in 2024.

The latest fortnightly report from the Brazilian Sugarcane and Bioenergy Industry Association (UNICA) shows that sugarcane crushing in Central-South Brazil stood at 34mt over the first half of October, an increase of 0.3% year-on-year. Sugar output over this period rose 1.25% YoY to 2.48mt. Meanwhile, the sugar mix in CS Brazil over the fortnight was 48.2%, up from 47.3% a year ago. This is despite prices suggesting that mills should favour a stronger ethanol mix. The cumulative cane crush so far this season still lags last year, down 2.8% to stand at 525mt, while cumulative sugar production totals 36mt, up 0.9% YoY.

data.title: Xerox: A 1-Year Review After Q3 2025
data.description:
Sometimes you get them right, and sometimes you get them wrong. In this case, I'm talking about Xerox Holdings Corporation (XRX). As you may know, if you follow my work, about 5-6% I allocate to what we might euphemistically call "troubled" companies. The company that used to be the leader in copying physical documents in a world where physical documents and copies are going out of style faster than horse-drawn carriages certainly qualifies as one such company. The deterioration since my last "BUY" rating for the company certainly speaks for itself, with a negative 65% since that last article a year ago.

I'm very glad that despite my own rating, I elected to mostly go for other risky companies that have not declined as much (though the one I chose has still not beaten the market, speaking about TUI AG (OTCPK:TUIFF)), but at least haven't lost 65%. My own position in Xerox was, as my communication suggested, a "small starter position".

But there's a difference between crashing that amount and being unrecoverable. When it comes to Xerox, in my last article, I made a case for why the company might be able to save ailing Lexmark.

So the question here becomes, because it's been less than 11 months since that piece, is 11 months enough to answer the question of whether the company is going bankrupt?

I would argue that it isn't.

This makes today, on earnings day of the 30th of October, an excellent day for updating my thesis on Xerox. Further, after a 60% decline and more, it might be fair to say that the company has dropped enough for me to be interested in investing after all.

Or am I?

Let's see here.

Xerox—Looking at the potential upside on a forward basis

Xerox is, and remains, the leader in print solutions. That is the company's battle cry and what the company has been focusing on for a long time. However, as mentioned above, this industry is currently declining. Will it see a revitalization? I doubt it. Can Xerox corner what there is left, and what, despite the decline, won't go away?

Printing is unlikely to disappear entirely. Certain things are likely to remain needed in printed form. I belong to the group that believes that printing will not disappear (nor physical material) but exist alongside digital—the question is at what size, and what will the market look at when that transformation is done.

Some arguments for printed/physical material are the physical permanence it offers, security, and in many cases, legal needs of some areas and geographies. We have several things here that can only be done with physical print and copies, and I believe that things have gone too extreme to the digital side anyway. So a drop like the one we're seeing today in 3Q25, or the company's drop since the 2024 period, doesn't really faze me, unless it's based on some very real, fundamental trends.

So what are the fundamental trends?

It's remarkable how similar XRX is to some companies I've invested in at extreme lows. I've invested in companies like Unum Group (UNM), Lincoln National Corporation (LNC), and Intrum AB (publ) (OTCPK:ITJTY) as well as TUI AG. The commonality for every single one of these investments was that at the time of investing, serious analysts and investors were calling for bankruptcy risks. In the case of Intrum, bonds were trading at below 75 cents on the dollar to par. It was perceived as serious in every single case.

Today, Unum is one of my better investments, Intrum is up 380%, and LNC is up more than 100%. I say this not to toot my own horn, but to tell you that I am comfortable with the ups and downs, provided I can understand them.

Xerox is risky. EPS for 2025 is definitely going negative (in my view). The company is B- B-rated (Intrum was worse, was at CCC-). The company still pays a yield, which is something, but it's reduced. Debt is actually high, especially since they bought Lexmark valued at $1.5B, which is now more than 3x the entire market capitalization of the company at a price of below $4/share.

If there is one trait I believe you need as an investor going into something like this (as of today, I'm long Xerox), it's patience. You need to be able to withstand tremendous amounts of pressure.

As you can see above, the company is far from done with anything substantial in its reinvention effort, and recovery is likely to take years. Of course, such an argument is an easy one to make, even if things just keep declining—but in this case, I do believe there is serious reason to expect recovery.

Why?

As I detailed in my original article, the company is likely to be able to leverage some key strengths. One, Lexmark's A4 platform, which is market-leading in the growing core market. It's also likely to be able to capitalize on Lexmark's A3 Models and OEM business, adding Xerox's considerable R&D. Expansion into APAC is likely to drive this further as well.

The company is also shifting by expanding into digital services and IT solutions, both very attractive businesses, with areas like document workflows, intelligent document processing, and the like (though Xerox is likely to encounter substantial competition here).

The reason, dear readers, that I am positive here is because many of the synergies mentioned above are starting to materialize. Revenue is growing, and not in small amounts. It's almost up 25% YoY, and FCF is growing (up over 20%), with debt repayment in full force. The company's adjusted earnings are still impaired, together with operating margins, but again, Xerox is in the absolute middle of a transformation that will take years. No one at the company has told us to expect this to be done at this time. The synergies, as mentioned in the 3Q25, are back-heavy, with most of them coming either in 2026 or 2027. The only thing the company is expecting to manage this year is the initial elimination of double overhead and the like—the heavy stuff comes in the next 36 months.

In retrospect, I did make one big mistake. I shouldn't have gone positive when I did. I should have entered at a "Hold" and waited for some of these issues and likely valuation trends to arrive. The fact that I did not invest a substantial amount of capital yet is no excuse at all—I gave the rating, and this gives responsibility (in my view). Timing of valuation is never easy, and I, of course (obviously), could not expect this, but given the transformations that I've been a part of as an investor, I should have drawn logical links between my tendency to enter too early at times and let this flow to ratings as well.

I didn't.

So let me be clearer this time. If you invest here, be ready for further declines—not guaranteed, but entirely possible. Xerox now has a load of debt that is unenviable, but most of that debt is laden toward the end of 2029-2039—by that time, we should know whether the company has succeeded or not.

The current timeline we have is 2026-2028. For the remainder of the year, the two positive takeaways and expectations we do have are a significant increase in FCF and an operating margin that's likely to trend toward 4-5%. If the company manages this, it will be good. I expect the company in 2026 to manage flat revenue but to be able to go over $300M of gross cost reductions, be able to really start reshaping things here, which should enable an FCF of above $300M per year.

That should start to allow for higher valuations here. My current forecast for 2026 is about a dollar's worth of EPS, compared to about the same level last fiscal, and for that to grow by 30-40% in fiscal 2027. Those improvements are likely, in my view, to come from the aforementioned synergies, growth in IT and digital (but I'm less optimistic on this than other analysts), and continued significant downpayment of debt. Since the M&A, almost every cent has gone to paying that down, the best current use of cash. The entry back into the mid-market for printing through the IJP900 is also something I consider to be likely to boost revenues.

Let's see what we can make of valuation after 3Q25.

Valuation for Xerox in 2025—look at 2026-2027

If you want to invest here, expect a recovery and profit period of no less than 3 years. My own forecast is this. As I said in my previous article, the market considers most of Xerox's sales to be worthless here. Why do I say this?

Because it's currently trading at less than 0.2 to sales, less than 0.7x to revenues, and a book valuation of 0.55x. This is, by the way, despite the fact that analysts are in agreement that revenue is likely to recover close to 2019 levels and above, potentially.

Same thing, by the way, with EBITDA.

So if both sales and earnings are likely to increase in the future, what could the company be worth?

Depends. And this is what makes a company like this interesting. Less than 1-2 years ago, when the company made $1/share in EPS, it traded at a 12-14x P/E. It currently trades at a negative P/E due to negative earnings this year. But if earnings were to recover to even close to this, and the market saw Xerox at a similar valuation, we're talking several hundred percent in returns.

And remember, the forecast you see above is not based on anything outlandish. If the company manages a net savings amount of $300M over the next few years, this would obviously substantially improve the company's cash flow, which in turn would increase net income. That is what I believe the recovery will come from. The $18/share fair value suggested above isn't even unrealistic, if the company manages this, Xerox traded at $18/share less than 2 years ago, and to my mind it was riskier back then because it didn't have the turnaround plan.

I've made it part of my investment approach to invest in distressed value, as I call it. Xerox, as I see it, is distressed value. The company is "down", but it's getting back up. I don't see any clear risk for bankruptcy or issues. The credit risk is considered high when you look at some bonds out there (try USU98401AE97, for instance), but when you look at what the company manages in EBITDA, revenues, debt payments, and the like, I don't really see the company going bankrupt.

This is a risky business, but if you're comfortable with what I consider "manageable risk," then this is for you. I'm taking and adding a long 0.25% position of my portfolio in Xerox at this time, resulting in a 0.29% position, and I expect a big payoff eventually, well over 100-200%.

My price target was $14/share. I'm cutting it to fair value $12/share at a $1.2/share EPS and a 10x P/E, with an upside of over 200%. My PT is therefore $8/share, but that makes this company a discount at this price.

Risks & Considerations

The market considers Xerox sales "worthless". It now also considers the earnings and most of the other parts of the company worthless, going by the way it's valuing the business. It's trading at less than 0.2x to sales, less than 0.7x to revenues, and less than 0.8x to book. The company's book value at this time is higher than the share price, and at almost $3-4/share, not a small amount more than the share price. With Lexmark, this is even better, and I continue to see the risks being outweighed by the positives.

Print declines and the company not succeeding in the turnaround remain the core risk here. Because this is such a substantial risk at this point, I would be careful investing at all here, unless you really are comfortable with the sort of risk/reward this offers but also requires in terms of patience.

There is a real potential, just like with Intrum, of a capital loss here, but I consider that to be very unlikely based on 3Q25 and the company seeming to move forward with its turnaround plan.

Count me in for now with the following thesis.

Thesis

  • Xerox offers, following the Lexmark deal and 3Q25 results, an attractive play on printing and printing services, as well as related IT. Following this, the company is becoming a vertically integrated producer and service-offering business, which is attractive, if high-risk.
  • I consider Xerox to be exceedingly cheap here, but the company is a speculative investment. However, this is something I am comfortable with, and I'm increasing my position.
  • I give the company an updated PT of $8/share and a fair value target of $12/share, above which I might sell, depending on how quickly it "went there". However, the potential for $18-20 over time is definitely there.

Here are my criteria and how the company fulfills them (italicized).

  • This company is overall qualitative.
  • This company is fundamentally safe/conservative & well-run.
  • This company pays a well-covered dividend.
  • This company is currently cheap.
  • This company has a realistic upside based on earnings growth or multiple expansion/reversion.

The company fulfills 1 out of 3 quality indicators and 2 out of 2 valuation indicators. That means 3/5 "stars" here, which is enough for an attractive thesis for the company. Based on this and a price target of $8/share share, I see a risk/reward-adjusted upside that's attractive enough for me. I give the company a "Buy" rating as of October 2025.

data.description:
Performance

The portfolio rose in absolute terms during Q3 but underperformed the MSCI ACWI index. Market concentration and style factors continued to be headwinds for the portfolio as returns have been dominated by AI stocks, cyclical companies and interest rate-sensitive financials, which are expected to benefit from deregulation.

Health Care holdings were the largest detractor. The sector has been under pressure due to US policy announcements aimed at lowering the price of healthcare. It has also proven a source of funds for investors looking to allocate into the AI theme. However, the announcement of a deal to provide lower prescription prices for government-funded Medicaid patients, but not the larger Medicare channel, may be a turning point for the sector as this lifts some of the regulatory overhang and provides greater clarity for research and development spending. This would be positive for the portfolio’s exposure to the drug discovery value chain.

Dynamics in the Financials sector have also worked against the portfolio, as easing of regulation favoured large-cap banks which benefit from an increase in capital market related activity. European regional bank KBC (OTCPK:KBCSY) rallied, but companies that typically deliver more consistent earnings through economic cycles, such as consultant Marsh & McLennan (MMC), have traded lower.

The lack of exposure to commodities within the Materials sector created a relative headwind, whilst sustainable construction materials maker Sika (OTCPK:SXYAY) came under pressure as the European construction market remains sluggish. Within Industrials, concerns over AI potentially disrupting business models were negative for data service providers, though better performance came from companies improving resource efficiency or benefiting from energy management and electricity grid investment.

Consumer Discretionary holdings have been a bright spot with eBay (EBAY), which delivered strong results after management refocussed the business on core platforms, rallying. The portfolio’s auto component company Aptiv (APTV) rebounded from its lows and gained momentum after it announced a divestment that allows it to focus on higher-margin advanced driving applications, Within Information Technology, companies with exposure to AI infrastructure also performed well.

Market overview

Global equities posted strong gains in Q3 2025, supported by resilient macroeconomic conditions, improving corporate earnings, fiscal stimulus and deregulation in the banking sector. However, market dynamics favouring hypergrowth, cyclical and value stocks have created headwinds for investors focused on quality, and market concentration increased over the period.

The passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) in the US was a key catalyst early in the quarter, providing short-term stimulus through extended tax cuts and incentives for domestic reshoring. While concerns linger over its longer-term impact on the US fiscal deficit and inflation, the OBBB helped lift investor sentiment, particularly in large-cap and technology stocks. The US Federal Reserve’s September interest rate cut also helped to support share prices and extend the risk-on rally in equities.

Emerging markets also performed well, buoyed by a weaker US dollar and supportive policy measures in China, which included new renewable energy standards targeting high-emission industries and support for the technology sector.

As we end Q3, US regulatory uncertainty has eased for Health Care stocks with the announcement of a deal between President Trump and drug company Pfizer to lower prescription drug prices for the government-funded Medicaid programme. In the short term, the US government shutdown may weigh on investor sentiment but historically these shutdowns have been resolved with little impact on equity markets.

Despite elevated valuations and increased market concentration, the investment team believe opportunities exist in stocks that have been de-rated despite strong earnings momentum and among companies demonstrating strong secular growth. The investment team remains focused on identifying businesses with durable growth drivers, sound management and attractive relative valuations.

The market has gone through another period of extreme concentration, with investors’ focus returning heavily to the AI theme and more cyclical or ‘hypergrowth’ stocks. This has resulted in a de-rating of many companies that the investment team believes continue to deliver strong fundamental performance and offer compelling structural growth.

For example, within Health Care, the portfolio is focussed on companies providing solutions which reduce the time or cost of drug development or improve patient outcomes through innovative products and services. The headwinds which have impacted the sector may now have reached a peak, leading investors to re-examine their appetite for these companies given the clear strength of sector tailwinds such as innovation of treatments and ageing populations.

Within Financials, the portfolio holds companies that are improving access to finance, and businesses which offer greater operational consistency such as data analytics, payment processors and financials consultancy businesses, rather than cyclical, leveraged 'balance sheet' financials. While these stocks are currently out of favour, we believe they remain well placed to benefit from structural growth and deliver superior long-term returns.

Finally, the portfolio retains holdings in a range of companies that the team sees as able to capture either revenue or cost opportunities through implementing AI innovation into their operations. Some of these stocks have been under pressure as investors anticipate disruption to their business models, while our investment team expects these companies, which include recruitment platforms, semiconductor chip designers and stock exchange operators, to benefit from their investments.

The investment team’s focus remains on finding companies with compelling structural growth, with quality characteristics at reasonable valuations. The team believes that the portfolio offers truly diversified exposure to multiple powerful trends across both environmental and social sustainability opportunities.

data.title: BDCs: The Liquid Alternative To Private Credit
data.description:
In the ever-evolving financial landscape, investors are constantly seeking innovative ways to diversify their portfolios and achieve optimal returns. Over the last decade, private equity and credit strategies have surged in popularity due to their unique return and yield potential. However, these typically come with the trade-off of reduced liquidity due to lockup periods. Recently, though, the importance of liquidity, especially in a market rife with uncertainties, is becoming more pronounced. In today's market, where liquidity is highly prized, public Business Development Companies (BDCs) present a compelling, liquid alternative to traditional private credit strategies.

Demand for Private Credit (and Liquidity) is Growing

Private credit strategies have soared in popularity, offering attractive return and diversification opportunities. They have granted investors access to niche markets and to distinct return profiles, which has fueled asset growth in the space, with market estimates predicting this growth to continue as assets under management are expected to eclipse $3 trillion by 2028.

Demand for Private Credit Expected to Continue | 2014-2024

data.title: Santacruz Silver Mining: Benefitting From Rising Silver And Production In 2026
data.description:
Thesis

Santacruz Silver Mining Ltd. (OTCPK:SCZMF) is a mining company, operating mines across Mexico and Bolivia. My investment thesis for the company is premised on SCZMF capitalizing on rising silver prices by increasing production. A rise in silver prices would have a disproportionate effect on the earnings of SCZMF, which has been substantiated below. Hence, SCZMF is an opportunity to leverage an ongoing silver upcycle. I anticipate an increase in production in 2026 from the Bolivar mine's production normalizing from Q4 2025 onwards and an increase in the proportion of ore processed from Level 960 of the Zimapan mine. These would decrease AISC and increase the silver equivalents produced by SCZMF. Due to these factors, I am initiating coverage on SCZMF with a Buy rating and a target price of $2.77 (equivalent to ~$11.08 on 4:1 consolidation due to NASDAQ listing).

About The Company

SCZMF works in the operation, acquisition, development, and exploration of mines across the Americas. The company primarily focuses on silver and zinc and secondarily on lead and copper. SCZMF owns mines across Bolivia and Mexico.

In Bolivia, the company has 100% ownership of the Tres Amigos and the Colquechita mines (the Caballo Blanco Group) and the Don Diego Processing Plant. The San Lucas Group is a unit of SCZMF and is involved in the ore feed sourcing and trading business and includes the Reserva mine. SCZMF also owns the Soracaya Exploration Asset in Bolivia. In 2022, SCZMF acquired the operational and profit-sharing rights of Glencore to the Bolivar and Porco mines. SCZMF is entitled to 45% of the assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses from these two mines.

In Mexico, the company owns the Zimapan mine and processing plant in Hidalgo.

Reduced AISC and Paid Off Glencore Consideration

SCZMF has successfully reduced its All-in Sustaining Cost (AISC) per Silver Equivalent Ounce (AgEq), particularly from its Bolivian mines due to the devaluation of BOB and the company shifting to using the real market rate as compared to the artificially fixed rate. This made BOB significantly cheaper for the company, enabling them to reduce the AISC in dollar terms.

Higher recoveries, especially in the Caballo Blanco Group, have also been a factor in favor of reducing AISC. On the contrary, Zimapan reported 17% higher AISC YoY for Q2 2025, partly due to the appreciation of the MXN, along with higher CapEx in the first half of 2025, which I expect to normalize towards the second half of the year. Overall, AISC reduced 8% YoY due to these factors.

The acquisition of the mining rights of Bolivar and Porco from Glencore in Q1 2022 came at a significant cost to SCZMF. A payment structure of $20 million upfront "Closing Cash Payment", coupled with a major $90 million "Deferred Consideration" which would be paid in equal installments over four years. The interest expense from the deferred portion significantly weighed down earnings. The debt obligation also led the management to restructure the business since the high consideration payable led to total equity being negative for 2022 and 2023.

Following the silver bull run since the end of Q1 2024, SCZMF's cash position increasingly strengthened due to operating leverage playing out. From a strong treasury position, the company exercised its "Accelerated Option Plan". This plan will see the company cover the entire outstanding obligation to Glencore by November 2025. This option is estimated to halve the outstanding consideration from $80 million to $40 million. The positive effect of the restructured payments is that the company can move faster towards the production of its mines, strengthening its cash position.

Production to Increase, with Marginal Rise in Head Grade

I expect SCZMF to see dampened production for Q3, mainly due to the Bolivar mine getting flooded in mid-May. This flood mainly affected the Pomabamba South and Tanane Reyes areas, both of which are high silver head grade veins. The Bolivar mine's ore is relatively rich in silver and has the highest head grade of silver among all mines operated by SCZMF, 237 g/ton (Q1 2025). Hence, the company gets more silver for a relatively lower AISC from this mine in particular. Following the flood, head grades for silver reduced by 20% and zinc by 7% QoQ for the Bolivar mine. Production from Bolivar is expected, by management, to fully recover by Q4 2025.

This shortfall is being partly mitigated by the San Lucas business, which has ramped up ore sourcing from other mines to cover for Bolivar. San Lucas sources ore from over 900 independent ore suppliers. This business offers stability in revenue and margins to SCZMF by establishing long-term supplier relationships to ensure stable ore flow.

Management views the Zimapan mine mainly as a business of high volume, since ore from it comprises ~45% of the total tons milled by SCZMF. Current volumes from Zimapan are 70,000-75,000 tons processed monthly. Increasing mining activity at Level 960 would improve silver head grades for Zimapan, from 79 g/ton to the range of 80-85 g/ton. Management expects copper head grades to hit 0.4%, significantly higher than the current levels of 0.24%. However, it is important to note that copper recoveries from Zimapan are quite low, at 47%. Considering this, it may be more realistic for copper head grades to reach the range of 0.32-0.35%.

Level 960 currently contributes 8,000 tons to the ore processed from Zimapan. The significant volumes already being mined at Zimapan, coupled with 40,000 tons more being added at full operation from Level 960 and the rise in head grades expected by management, lead me to expect an increase up to 2.5 million AgEq yearly, taking the lower end of head grade estimates.

SCZMF owns the Soracaya Project in the Potosí Department, Bolivia. This is a high-grade resource, with the inferred silver head grade being 260 g/ton. The inferred lead head grade is also quite high, at 7.23%. Mining at these grades would improve the overall AISC for SCZMF, making Soracaya a valuable asset. SCZMF has finalized the preliminary mine plan, and is currently focusing on completing permitting and moving the project towards full construction. Once the Soracaya Project moves towards production, I expect it to contribute significantly to the revenue of SCZMF.

Tailwinds For Silver, Flat Zinc Outlook

The company has most of its revenue coming from two metals - silver and zinc.

Industrial demand for silver is increasing due to the ongoing trend of decarbonization. This is most prominent in the photovoltaic demand for silver due to the solar energy boom, which accounts for over 17% of total silver demand. I expect this proportion to rise by 2030, as solar PV manufacturer demand increases, especially in China, where solar capacity is set to double by 2030. Silver is also a critical component of the digital world due to its role in semiconductor chips and PCBs.

Silver has another type of demand that is pushing its price: investment demand. With the Fed predicted, by the CME FedWatch tool, to ease rates, silver demand in the short term will go higher due to its use as an inflation hedge. The Central Bank of Russia plans to invest $535 million in precious metals, with an explicit mention of silver, from 2025 to 2027. This marks a landmark shift from decades of central banks' avoidance of maintaining meaningful silver reserves. In the short term, silver may be highly volatile due to the currently uncertain nature of global trade.

Approximately 70% of silver produced is as a by-product of mining other minerals such as lead, copper, and zinc. Due to the low proportion of primarily silver-producing mines, supply is largely inelastic since it would be uneconomical for miners to expand operations if silver is just a by-product. At the same time, SCZMF operates primarily silver mines and may be able to capitalize on the ongoing cycle of silver demand by ramping up ore extraction and processing capacity.

Zinc prices are currently increasing due to supply constraints that are being outpaced by demand. I expect this supply issue to be temporary and zinc prices to normalize.

The market currently faces a constrained supply of zinc. Mine depletion and closures, with ore smelting and treatment becoming uneconomical, are the major reasons for tightening supply. The current shortage seems evident if we look at the current global zinc inventory crisis. The London Metal Exchange currently holds inventory enough to satisfy ~3 days of global consumption, which is uncharacteristically low.

These factors have led to the present rise in zinc prices, but it is important to note that the current inventory crisis and supply squeeze due to low zinc ore concentrate availability causing uneconomical smelting may be temporary. I believe that the current price increase is simply a result of inventory positioning, and supply will soon return to meet the demand.

Earnings Projections And Valuation

Before proceeding with earnings projections and valuation of SCZMF, it is important to clarify that all numbers of EPS and price targets are calculated on a total of 365,384,489 common shares issued and outstanding. This clarification is necessary since the company recently announced its intent to get listed on the NASDAQ, which would involve either a consolidation of shares up to 10:1, with 4:1 being the more probable figure according to management.

To project earnings, I have to assume certain commodity prices, which are notoriously unpredictable. Due to the above factors, I anticipate silver to average $52 USD/oz in 2026, in line with estimates. I expect zinc, copper, and lead prices to be largely flat. Here are my assumptions (these are my assumptions taken of the average price throughout each period):

I estimate EBITDA/Net Income/EPS for Q3 2025 to be $39.8 million/$21.1 million/$0.06. EBITDA for the period was calculated by marginally lowering AISC due to the high CapEx sustained in Zimapan in the first half of the year, which I expect to normalize in the second half. In Q4, however, I expect a significant improvement with the increase in commodity prices, ore from Level 960 comprising an increase in the proportion of Zimapan's ore milled, and production from Bolivar coming back on track, which will be of a higher silver head grade and slightly reduced AISC. Due to these considerations, I estimate EBITDA/net income/EPS for Q4 2025 to be $61.14 million/$42.6 million/$0.12. I have assumed silver prices to average $52/oz in 2026, which is relatively modest compared to some bullish forecasts. This 47% increase in the price of silver from 2025 will have an immense effect on profitability, with projected EBITDA and net income for 2026 growing by 113% and 177%, respectively.

Conducting a sensitivity analysis for bull, bear, and base case scenarios, here are the projected EPS figures for 2026:

Coming to the valuation of SCZMF, it is currently undervalued from the perspective of TTM EV/EBITDA, and 1-year forward EV/EBITDA; the company is currently valued at 3.16 and 1.48, respectively. It is evident that the market is pricing in a major discount due to the risk associated with the business. However, I expect this to adjust slightly upwards once strong earnings are released for Q4 2025, as anticipated by me. My target for EV/EBITDA for the year-end of 2026 is 3.3. This is extremely conservative but takes into account risks associated with currency, silver as a commodity, and assumptions of the mines' operations running smoothly. Along with this, peers sharing similar jurisdiction risk, such as Fortuna Mining Corp. (FSM) and Hochschild Mining plc (OTCQX:HCHDF) have higher TTM EV/EBITDA multiples of 4.2 and 6, respectively (sourced from Seeking Alpha). The discount as compared to HCHDF seems justified due to shorter mine lives of SCZMF. Another peer SCZMF can be compared to is Silvercorp Metals Inc. (SVM), which trades at an EV/EBITDA multiple of 9. This can be justified due to SVM operating in China, causing a difference in jurisdiction risk and shorter mine lives of SCZMF. With these assumptions, the target price from an EV/EBITDA multiple of 3.3 comes out to $3.36.

I also evaluated SCZMF on the basis of the NAV by calculating the NAV of each operational mining project on the basis of proven and probable mineral reserves of currently operational mines. The current value of market cap/NAV is 0.43. The NAV calculation excludes the Soracaya Project and the cash generated by the non-SCZMF ore processed by the San Lucas Group from independent miners. This includes a major assumption that the Zimapan mine would have reserves to last 8 years of mining, as its mineral reserves are not supported currently by any viability study.

A market cap/NAV of 0.43 cannot be justified, even accounting for the usual discount on smaller mining companies in geographies like Latin America. Including the Soracaya Project, this number would be even lower. The current obligations of all mining resources would be paid off by November, ensuring more of the mines' earnings go towards increasing cash, which can then be used to acquire more mines to further increase the scale of operations of SCZMF. Due to this, I feel that a 0.75 market cap/NAV ratio is justified to value the company, which would put its immediate share price at $2.48/share. The huge gap between both valuation methods can be explained by the fact that the Caballo Blanco Group, Bolivar, and Porco mines' proven and probable reserves are quite low and would only last the company a few more years. However, the cash generated from these mines can be put to use in acquiring mines with a higher NAV, which can replace these mines once their reserves are exhausted.

Using equal weights for both valuation methods, I have come up with a target share price of $2.77 for the end of 2026 (~$11.08 considering a 4:1 consolidation). This implies an upside of 92%, due to which I give SCZMF a buy rating.

Risks To The Thesis

The entire case for being long SCZMF is heavily reliant on silver prices, and any major drop in these prices that is sustained for a long period would mean that SCZMF would not benefit from the disproportionate effects of a rise in silver prices. However, short-term volatility is inevitable considering the uncertain state of global trade currently due to tariffs levied by the US. This risk can be quantified by a scenario in which silver averages only $35 for 2026, in which case EPS projections would drop from $0.73 to $0.34, a 53% drop.

The management of SCZMF has disclosed,

Production at the Zimapan Mine is not supported by a feasibility study on mineral reserves demonstrating economic or technical viability or any other independent economic study under NI 43-101. Accordingly, there is increased uncertainty and higher economic and technical risks of failure associated with production operations at the Zimapan Mine.

Source: Q2 2025 MD&A Interim Report (Page 18)

Accordingly, it is highly critical for the company that Zimapan stays operational, as any operational or technical failure would have a significantly negative impact on SCZMF's revenue. Beyond just Zimapan, it is important for operations to go smoothly for the valuations and earnings projections to be met. Any disruption, such as the Bolivar mine flooding this year, would have a negative impact on the ore processed by SCZMF. The thesis playing out is highly reliant on smooth operations.

Another major risk to the thesis is any currency headwinds, for example, the recent appreciation of the MXN with respect to the USD. Any such significant appreciation of MXN or BOB would increase AISC, decreasing margins and adversely affecting profitability for SCZMF.

It is also important to keep track of zinc, as a significant proportion of SCZMF's revenue comes from it. Any drop in zinc prices would have a negative impact on zinc's contribution to AgEq/oz sold.

Since SCZMF has a small market cap, investors may face issues of illiquidity at times, which is a major risk to consider.

Conclusion

To conclude, SCZMF currently seems to be an attractive investment option, with 92% upside. The company is positioned well to capitalize on the ongoing silver upcycle by increasing production. Though there are significant risks associated with the company, strong projected earnings growth and undervaluation make it a Buy.

Eagle Point Credit Co. LLC (ECC) has always attracted attention with its preferred shares, despite the high fees and relatively low risk-adjusted returns offered by its common shares, which we are not fans of. But this time our interest was caught by its low-duration bonds. Despite the common stock trading at a premium for many years, and now at a discount, and all the risks, we assume that the bond's yield is enough to compensate for them, because overall we will earn a return.

Company Overview

  • Current market capitalization: close to $867 million

  • Nominal value of exchange-traded bonds: $285.5 million
  • Nominal value of preferred shares: $116.45 million
  • Credit quality:

The credit quality of ECC's underlying CLO debt is around a B score:

This might be quite misleading to some readers, as it suggests that ECC's underlying holdings are B-rated, which is not the case. The largest part of ECC's portfolio is in CLO equity, which, in our opinion, is several notches lower in credit quality. This is clearly evident in the fund's volatile earnings.

Baby bonds

ECC has four low-duration baby bonds: (ECCV), (ECCW), (ECCU), (ECCX). The call dates of all are passed, except ECCU, with a call date on 06/30/2027. All are with yields to worst above 7%, but our attention is caught by ECCV with its highest yield of 8.35% and price below par. On 01/12/2022, 3.48 million notes of ECCV were issued, each with a par value of $25, or gross proceeds of 87 million. ECCV pays interest distributions of 5.38% per annum, or $1.34375 annually, in the form of $0.3359375 quarterly. Below are the basic metrics of the bond:

Being a CEF, ECC has to limit its leverage. Here is a quote from the prospectus of ECCV:

"We are required under current law to have an asset coverage of at least 300%, as measured at the time of borrowing and calculated as the ratio of our total assets (less all liabilities and indebtedness not represented by senior securities) over the aggregate amount of our outstanding senior securities representing indebtedness. With respect to senior securities that are stocks (i.e., shares of our Preferred Stock), we are required under current law to have an asset coverage of at least 200%, as measured at the time of the issuance of any such shares of preferred stock and calculated as the ratio of our total assets (less all liabilities and indebtedness not represented by senior securities) over the aggregate amount of our outstanding senior securities representing indebtedness plus the aggregate liquidation preference of any outstanding shares of preferred stock."

We are facing a lot of questions about yield calculations, and we calculate them using the XIRR function in Google Sheets, which is supposed to be the most precise way when dealing with ex-dividend dates. It is a bit more work than just finding a random bond yield calculator, but at least we try to ensure the data is accurate. Below you can see ECCV's yields to maturity at different prices:

For ECCV to trade at 7.19%, like its sibling ECCX, it would have to trade at a price nearly 80 cents higher than it is now (or close to 3.4%). Let's say we expect it to give us 2% alpha instead of 3.4%. If this hypothetical alpha is capitalized for 1 month, the annual rate of return for ECCV approaches over 20%. Over 20% per year from just one mispriced bond.

Comparison with other low-duration baby bonds.

Below are shown fixed-rate low-duration baby bonds that trade below par and have maturity dates, with their yields to worst and years to maturity:

ECCV compensates its investors with a significant spread above some BDC bonds. Although riskier, we believe that such a low-duration instrument deserves a lower spread. If we include the yield curve of the BDCs, ECCV offers close to a 3% spread above the benchmarks in the sector:

We cannot argue that ECC is safer than ARCC, for example, but we are well compensated for taking on the extra risk, and it is still a regulated company with leverage restrictions.

Comparison with the common stock

Below is shown a chart between ECC and the oldest bond of ECC - ECCX:

The chart illustrates the difference between the common stock and the bond of ECC. One is high risk, the other is high yield. To further compare the alternatives, we need to add some leverage to ECCV and compare its expected return to the historical return on NAV of ECC:

The expected return of the leveraged ECCV position is quite similar to the 10-year return of ECC, but ECCV can achieve the same result with less risk.

Conclusion

ECCV stands out among the low-duration baby bonds with a high yield-to-risk ratio. Despite the company's high costs and leverage, the current yield to maturity of over 8% and trading below par suggest good compensation for the risk taken. The widening spread against 3-year Treasury notes also suggests potential undervaluation. Therefore, ECCV looks like an attractive option for investors.

data.title: Shake Shack: Port In The Storm In A Battered Sector (Upgrade)
data.description:
We're in the thick of the Q3 earnings season, and so far the earnings cycle hasn't proven kind to businesses that are directly exposed to weaker consumer spending. This is especially true in the restaurant space, where industry giants like Chipotle (CMG) have tanked, citing macroeconomic pressures that are acting as an overhang on traffic.

Shake Shack (SHAK), however, is proving amply that the sector isn't all shifting in the same direction and that underneath the headline scares, subtle market share shifts are taking place - with Shake auShack as a possible beneficiary. The stock is up ~2% since earnings, which is notable when most of the sector is down double-digits in sympathy with Chipotle's horrendous print.

I last wrote a neutral article on Shake Shack in August, when the stock was trading near $110 per share. Since then, Shake Shack has seen a ~20% correction, while its metrics have only improved: showcasing accelerating comp sales and superb cost management when most of the rest of the industry has faced declining comp sales and a surge in pressure from labor costs and food inflation. I'm biting the bullet here and upgrading Shake Shack to a buy rating.

In my view, there are now many reasons to be positive on Shake Shack. The core tenets of the bull case for this company are:

  • Category leader with a reputation for quality. Shake Shack's roots trace back to Michelin-starred chef Danny Meyer, and the company has since earned a reputation as a gourmet burger at a fast-casual price. The company has a massive white space for expansion in the U.S. I also think that while rivals like McDonald's (MCD) are trying to win back traffic by focusing on price, Shake Shack has an opportunity to distinguish itself for quality.
  • Licensing deals and overseas growth position Shake Shack for tremendous expansion beyond the core domestic market. The Shake Shack brand is beloved in the U.S., and the company is beginning to capitalize on this by expanding into franchise deals overseas. Licensing revenue is growing at a >20% y/y clip, nearly double the company average and providing a high-margin revenue stream for the company.
  • Substantial progress in bringing down labor costs. Shake Shack is achieving substantial operating margin improvement despite a tough and inflationary economy, in which most of its peers are facing deleverage on labor costs. The company's new labor staffing model has allowed it to shave down significant costs on store labor, padding its earnings growth despite more tepid same-store sales performance. We think more machine-based automation (such as Chipotle's Autocado) could be a further catalyst down the line for the company's back-kitchen processes.
  • Managing inflating costs well. Though the price of beef has increased in the double digits, the company notes that it has achieved deflation on other costs, helping the company to reduce the bite of inflation by Q4 of this year.

And while I think it still may be a stretch to call Shake Shack a value stock, I do think that its "port in the storm" performance amid a tougher quarter for the rest of the industry, plus its recent downside from August peaks, have positioned the stock well for gains.

At current share prices near $91, Shake Shack trades at a market cap of $3.90 billion. After we net off the $357.8 million of cash and $247.5 million of debt on Shake Shack's latest balance sheet, the company's resulting enterprise value is $3.79 billion.

For next year, FY26, Wall Street analysts are expecting Shake Shack to hit $1.65 billion in revenue, or 13% y/y growth. The company notes it is planning to open 55-60 new Shacks next year (15-16% unit growth versus the ~375 stores it will end FY25 with, based on a range of 15-20 openings in Q4). If we conservatively assume the company achieves ~100 bps of y/y adjusted EBITDA margin expansion next year to a 15.7% margin (the company has been improving restaurant-level margins at close to a ~2 point pace in recent quarters), adjusted EBITDA in FY26 would be $259.1 million, or ~21% y/y growth. This positions Shake Shack at a 14.6x EV/FY26 adjusted EBITDA multiple.

Now, with proven strong execution amid a tough macro climate, Shake Shack fares quite well from a value/growth perspective against other restaurant peers. Shake Shack is trading in line/below Chipotle, despite the latter's growth challenges and its nearly nonexistent comp sales growth.

To me, it's time to pick up shares of Shake Shack while it's strengthening its hand against a flailing restaurant industry.

Q3 recap

Let's now go through Shake Shack's latest quarterly results in greater detail. The Q3 earnings summary is shown below:

Shake Shack's revenue grew 16% y/y to $367.4 million, beating Wall Street's expectations of $363.8 million (+15% y/y) by a one-point margin. Of course, all eyes are fixed on Shake Shack's comp sales trends. In Q3, Shake Shack surprised industry watchers by achieving a 3-point reaccelerating to 5% comp sales growth. Even more surprising is that traffic rebounded to 1% expansion, after three quarters of negative traffic. We note that comp sales accelerated in all of Shake Shack's domestic markets, while also hitting positive growth in all markets except its home base of New York City.

As a reminder, comp sales represents sales growth in existing store locations, excluding newly opened or newly closed stores. It decomposes into price growth (from price increases as well as customers' menu mix choices) and traffic (the number of transactions that Shake Shack sells). We note that Shake Shack's core rival in the fast-casual space, Chipotle, also just reported earnings with a much more deflating result of 0.3% comp sales (with traffic still negative, and pricing providing all the uplift).

Meanwhile, the company also continues to pull in more revenue from its franchise partners: licensing revenue grew 21% y/y to $14.6 million, or 4% of total sales.

We also applaud Shake Shack for its efficient cost management. The company notes that its standardized labor model has allowed the company to reduce labor costs to 24.9% of revenue, down 310bps y/y.

Again, we have to draw out the comparison to Chipotle here, which saw labor increase 30 bps y/y to 25.2% of revenue. Shake Shack is getting ahead of rising labor costs by taking every opportunity to slice waste out of its labor model.

This efficiency mindset carries over into the company's management of commodities as well. While higher beef costs did contribute to a 110 bps rise in food and paper costs as a percentage of revenue, we are heartened by the fact that Shake Shack's Q4 outlook implies blended food and paper cost inflation to moderate down to low single-digit inflation, from mid single digit inflation in Q3. The company says that it has achieved deflation in many items in its food costs that have helped to take away the sting from mid-teens beef price inflation.

Shake Shack's restaurant-level profit margins, which is a measure of profitability excluding corporate overhead, rose 26% yen to/y to $81 million, with restaurant margins improving 180 bps y/y to 22.8%.

Shake Shack's adjusted EBITDA of $54 million also grew 18% y/y, consistent with the company's 3-year financial targets of growing adjusted EBITDA at a ~teens pace.

Key takeaways

I've been on the sidelines and skeptical about Shake Shack since the start of 2025. That said, I now see a substantial opportunity to capitalize on this company's growth as it evidently takes market share from a hobbled fast-casual restaurant industry, while the stock's own declines since midsummer have positioned its valuation multiples much more favorably. Buy here with confidence.

data.title: Chart Of The Day: Two Fed Words Fuel Two-Year Surge
data.description:
By Mike Larson

All it took was two words. Two words from Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell to send 2-year Treasury Note yields surging. So... what should traders do?

We’ll get into that in a minute. But first, take a look at the MoneyShow Chart of the Day, which shows the one-week change in 2-year yields. You can see the 2-year was yielding 3.5% late last week. But it shot up to 3.62% on Wednesday and remained elevated yesterday.

(Source: Wall Street Journal)

Why did that happen when the Fed cut the federal funds rate by 25 basis points? Because Powell said it was “far from” certain the Fed would follow this week’s cut with another one at the policy meeting that concludes Dec. 10.

Since the 2-year yield incorporates expectations about future Fed moves - and expectations for a December cut were high - the surprise remarks caused yields to spike. That, in turn, fueled fresh volatility in several corners of the capital markets.

So, what should you do? Don’t panic. But do keep an eye on the bond market to see if we get more follow-through at the short end of the curve.

If yields keep rising, it will likely give the dollar a boost... restrain any rebound in precious metals prices... and put pressure on high-growth, high-valuation stocks (Big Tech, I’m looking at you!)

The last of those three consequences could be especially important. After all, a ton of money is invested in the tech sector. Plus, we’ve already had questions swirling in the markets about the sustainability of AI spending - and some AI stocks swooning in response. The last thing the group needs is another hurdle to jump over.

Economy

  • The presser was hawkish with Powell emphasizing that a December cut was by no means assured. Stock and bond markets are falling.

  • The Fed cut rates as expected by 25bp and also announced the end of its balance sheet reduction also as expected. There was a surprise dissent to the cut by Jeffrey Schmid of the Kansas City Fed with an expected dissent favoring a 50bp cut by Stephen Miran. The statement was largely unchanged with no indication of future rate cuts. The bond market traded off slightly as the dissent was a negative, and the stock market was largely unchanged. We continue to expect a December rate cut and three more cuts in 2026 to get the Fed funds rate to the neutral rate of 2.75%. We project that core PCE will decline to the 2% area by the end of 2026 as the shelter component of CPI has finally started to reflect the decline in market rents. In fact, our real-time measure of inflation utilizing market rents has already declined to the 2% area for core PCE.

  • Friday’s inflation print was very bullish, as the critical owner’s equivalent rent component declined to only .1% vs. .4% in the prior month and 3.8% Y/Y. This decline is critical as it finally reflects market rent declines and implies that core PCE will decline to the Fed’s arbitrary 2% target by the end of 2026 as measured shelter inflation finally reflects the decline in market rents.

  • The monetary base is the critical leading indicator of inflation and GDP growth. M1 and M2 have become outdated indicators after the GFC, as banks now have massive excess reserves, so the Fed can no longer control the size of bank balance sheets to restrict credit. In addition, non-bank lending has grown exponentially, further limiting the importance of M1 and M2 relative to the monetary base.

    • The monetary base is flat Y/Y vs. a normal growth rate of 5%, which is deflationary and could lead to a recession.

  • The only reason the US economy is not in recession is the housing sector has become less cyclical as home building has remained muted since the GFC, with only an average of 1.1MM homes started, with a peak of 1.8MM. During the 10 years prior to the GFC, starts averaged 1.7MM with a peak of 2.3MM.

  • The “Hatfield Rule” is a recession indicator which states that if housing starts drop below 1.1MM there will be a recession. It is superior to the “Sahm” rule, as housing is a leading indicator and employment is a lagging indicator.

  • Consequently, there is a significant shortage of homes in the US of approximately 4MM homes. Also, there is now an active group of investors buying new homes to rent, which provides for more resilient demand than has existed in the past. A decline in the housing sector accounted for 12 out of 13 post-WWII recessions.

    • CPI-R continues to be below CPI-U (Core CPI) and has been a reliable predictor of CPI-U.

Continuing claims also remain elevated at almost 2MM.

    • Private investment GDP drives economic cycles.

  • Tariffs are positive for economic growth in the medium to long term as the additional revenue from tariffs reduces the federal budget deficit and crowding out of private investment. Savings and investment are 70% correlated with GDP growth globally, according to an IMF study.

    • We forecast that the federal budget deficit declines to $1.45 trillion in fiscal 26, with tariffs contributing $400 billion of incremental revenue based on an expected average tariff rate of 17.5%.

Stock Market

  • We are also initiating a 2026 year-end target for the S&P of 7,700 based on a 23x multiple of our 2027 S&P earnings per share estimate of $335.

  • Given the decline in rates and our bullish outlook on stocks, we recommend large-cap dividend stocks, small-cap stocks, and high-yield fixed income.

Bond Market

  • We project that the 10-year treasury trades in the 3.5-4.0% range as the terminal rate of expected Fed funds trends down to the 2.75% area as reported inflation slowly reflects the decline in real-time inflation.

  • The economy is slowing, and weakness in the US job market will likely force the Fed to cut 2-3 times this year. GDP growth has only averaged 1.5% this year, and the interest-sensitive construction and residential sectors have contracted over the last year in response to tight Fed policy.

  • Importantly, 2 members of the 7-member Federal Reserve Board came out for a July rate cut. The market had failed to recognize that tariffs are recessionary/deflationary as the tax revenue reduces the deficit.

    • US 10-year bonds are 70% correlated to the expected terminal Fed Funds rate and 25% correlated to global bonds (see attached slide). The budget deficit is relatively static and has been in the 5% of GDP range for years, so it is not a driver of interest rates in the short to medium term.

  • Market-implied policy rate continues to forecast 10-year yields with a 1% average spread.

  • We recommend investors add high-yield bonds and preferred stocks, as we do not expect a big increase in defaults, and we expect treasury rates to decline below 4% as the economy weakens.

Commodities

  • We lowered our 2025 target on oil from $80 to $70 (range of $60-80) as it has become clear that Trump will use his influence with the Saudis and Russia to limit price increases despite tighter sanctions on Iran. This policy will offset a good portion of one-time price increases from tariffs. We do not expect an increase in US production. We do see support for oil below $60, as most forecasters ignore the price elasticity of supply and demand for oil. Middle East wars will only impact prices if oil production facilities are destroyed.

  • Artificial intelligence and data centers have opened new growth prospects for natural gas midstream companies to supply gas-fired power plants. Natural gas plants have some of the shortest times to build, and we believe they are best positioned to supply reliable power quickly.
